poem:
**Revolution on Air**

In April's turning warmth,  
a needle drops,  
static dances in the sunlit room.  
Johnnie Walker, unchained,  
his voice a rebel tide,  
sweeps through dusty hours—  
a melody of laughter,  
of music, of joy shared  
through invisible waves.  
Rules dissolve into riffs,  
and the afternoon breathes anew.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘I hated playing by the rules’: Johnnie Walker, the empathetic radio DJ with a rebel spirit The Radio 1 listings for 26 April 1969, when Johnnie Walker made his BBC broadcasting debut, in some ways have a dated air, also boasting shows featuring “Kenny Everett and his granny phone” and “Emperor Rosko’s Midday spin”. However the entry at 2pm for Walker – “The Saturday afternoon listening revolution with music and happiness for all to share”". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
